chapters.content:
Chapter 1 - Reference materials

Overview
A gas technician/fitter installs, services, and maintains gas equipment and piping systems on a daily basis, and the systems and types of equipment they work on are constantly changing. Therefore, it is important to have access to current reference materials. Moreover, gas-fired equipment must be installed and serviced according to codes, regulations, and manufacturer specifications.

Terminology
- Manufacturer service bulletins: Instructions from a manufacturer with guidelines for servicing and maintaining appliances or equipment, or updates on equipment problems and provisions for solutions
- Manufacturer specifications: Specifications and certified installation instructions from a manufacturer for its appliances and equipment

Types of reference materials
A gas technician/fitter needs to reference code books, installation manuals, government acts, regulations, bulletins, and directives, as well as manufacturer manuals, specifications, and service bulletins.

Code books and manuals

CSA B149.1, Natural gas and propane installation code
CSA B149.1 has ten main clauses, as identified in the table of contents. You can find a topic either by searching the table of contents by clause title, or by using the key word index at the back of the Code. Searching the index is the preferred method as it shows cross references on the topic in various clauses of the Code.

CSA B149.2, Propane storage and handling code
CSA B149.2 has nine main clauses, as identified in table of contents. Similarly, you can search either the table of contents or the index.

CSA B149.3, Code for the field approval of fuel-burning appliances and equipment
CSA B149.3 contains requirements for the field approval and assembly of non-certified or upgraded gas appliances, equipment, fuel-related components, and accessories located downstream of an appliance's manual shut-off valve.

This Code consists of 20 clauses and Annexes A to K (all informative), which are listed in the table of contents. Annex B contains symbols and diagrams.

Acts, regulations, and directives

Provincial acts
An act is a piece of government legislation that defines or assigns responsibilities and enables the writing of regulations. A gas technician/fitter should be familiar with the sections of the applicable act(s) pertaining to their responsibilities.

Important: The title of the act(s) that deal with the installation of gas equipment, the certification of gas technicians/fitters, or both, varies from province to province.

Provincial regulations
A regulation is a piece of government legislation made under the authority of an act. A regulation is more specific than an act. For example, there are usually separate regulations for certification or apprenticeship, gas installations, and propane storage.

Safety directives/bulletins
The provincial authority having jurisdiction (AHJ) may periodically issue directives and bulletins pertaining to product approval or installation practices. The AHJ is responsible for the adoption of national installation codes, often with changes.

Manufacturer specifications
Manufacturers publish specifications and certified installation instructions for their appliances and equipment. It is crucial to read manufacturer publications before installing an appliance and ensure that the specifications and instructions pertain to the appliance being installed.

Compliance with the manufacturer's certified instructions is a legal requirement. CSA B149.1 states that "[a]n appliance, accessory, component, equipment, or any other item shall be installed in accordance with the manufacturer's certified instructions and this Code".

Typically, the following information is in gas appliance manufacturer publications:
• Size of area needed for installation and service
• Physical dimensions of the equipment
• Model and part numbers
• Gas input rate and pressure requirements, and combustion parameters
• Venting material and configuration requirements
• Air supply requirements
• Electrical diagrams and rating
• Operating sequence
• Maintenance requirements
• Troubleshooting tips

Manufacturer service bulletins
Manufacturer service bulletins give the service technician guidelines for servicing and maintaining an appliance or equipment. Manufacturers also publish updates on equipment problems and provisions for solutions when necessary.

The internet is a powerful tool for staying up-to-date on the latest information available concerning a specific appliance or component. A gas technician/fitter should regularly check the manufacturer website for any new information or service bulletins regarding the appliance or component being installed or serviced.

Important: Carefully read all materials available from the manufacturer.

topics: Manufacturer certified installation and service manuals
chapters.content:
Chapter 2 - Manufacturer technical manuals and specifications

Overview
A gas technician/fitter requires manufacturer technical manuals and specifications for installation, parts replacement, and troubleshooting procedures.

Terminology
- Manufacturer certified installation and service manual: A document from a manufacturer with all the necessary information for the installation and basic maintenance of an appliance
- Troubleshooting procedure: A series of specific steps to locate the source of a problem to make a product or process operational again

Manufacturer's installation data
Manufacturers provide certified installation and service manuals with their appliances. Although the literature varies between companies and products, these manuals include all the necessary information for the installation and basic maintenance of an appliance.

Gas appliance manufacturer installation instructions typically include a list of tools and measuring instruments needed to complete the installation, as well as instructions on how to uncrate, locate, install, test, and commission the appliance.

Model number
Manufacturers often publish one set of instructions for various models of the same series of appliances.

Tools and hardware
Manufacturers often indicate the tools and hardware required for the installation and may indicate when hardware is supplied.

Wiring and piping
Most manuals have wiring and piping diagrams that often come with schedules (gas orifice schedules) and keys (wiring diagram keys describing components).

Replacement parts
Manuals will sometimes specify details on replacement parts (e.g., wire types, specifications).

Troubleshooting problems
The troubleshooting section provides general information about troubleshooting problems. Its purpose is to help develop a consistent, analytical approach to troubleshooting.

Troubleshooting procedure (7 steps):

Step 1 — Know the system
Study the manufacturer technical manuals, and know how the system works. Keep up with the latest service bulletins.

Step 2 — Ask questions and look for symptoms
Ask all possible questions to anyone who might know what happened. Examine the equipment and look for symptoms (signs of abnormal operation).

Step 3 — Evaluate your information
Use the supplied manufacturer manuals, charts, and service suggestions, together with your experience, to evaluate any information concerning the problem.

Step 4 — Make a trial run
Cycle the burner system and observe. Take note of any new information gathered.

Step 5 — Re-evaluate
Go over your list of possible causes and decide which are most likely and easiest to verify. Remember that more than one factor may be contributing.

Step 6 — Test your conclusions
Perform a second test run to verify if your evaluation is correct. More than one re-evaluation test might be necessary.

Step 7 — Correct the condition(s)
Adjust or replace the faulty part(s). Do a final run-through to confirm you have solved the problem. When ordering replacement parts, provide the model number.

Manufacturer troubleshooting guides
Manufacturers provide troubleshooting guides that list:
- Nature of trouble
- Possible cause
- Service required

How to obtain service assistance
When contacting the manufacturer, have the following information:
1) Model and serial number (from name plate)
2) Address where equipment is located
3) Name and address of installer and service agency
4) Date of original installation and service work dates
5) Details of the problem
6) List of people contacted regarding the issue

Chapter 3 - Technical drawings and diagrams

Overview
Technical drawings and diagrams communicate information about equipment, systems, and installations. Understanding how to read these is essential for gas technicians/fitters.

Types of technical drawings

Orthographic projections
Orthographic projections provide separate two-dimensional views of an object. The three most commonly projected views are: top, front, and left side (or right side).

Schematic diagrams
Schematics show only the connections, functions, and flow within a system, not the actual size, shape, or location of components.

Wiring diagrams
Wiring diagrams show how and where wires are connected, and how they run between devices. They are extremely useful for initial wiring and troubleshooting. Solid lines represent factory wiring; broken/dotted lines represent field wiring.

Lines and symbols
Different lines convey different meanings on technical drawings:

Object line: Thick lines tracing the visible outline of an object

Hidden line: Thin, equally spaced, broken lines showing surfaces and features that are hidden

Centreline: Thin, broken lines with long and short lines spaced alternately, indicating exact centre of object

Extension line: Thin lines extending object lines out to convenient space for dimensioning

Dimension line: Thin lines terminating with arrowheads, giving measured dimensions

Section lines: Hatch marks identifying a sectional view

Break lines: Help shorten the view of long uniform sections

Piping symbols and lines
Symbols are shorthand signs used on drawings. Common fitting symbols include: elbows, reducing couplings, plugs, caps, crosses, wyes, tees.

Piping line symbols distinguish various types of pipes: cold water, hot water, hot water return, acid waste, compressed air, fire line, gas line, vacuum.

Supplements to mechanical drawings

Specifications
A specifications book (written description of work to be performed) supplements the set of technical drawings. The specification is an integral part of a contract document and is generally considered the most important document after the written agreement.

When there is disagreement between a specification and a drawing, the specification is considered correct.

Scale
Scale allows description of large or small machines on standard size paper. First number refers to dimensions used to draw the object; second number refers to object's actual size.

Scale types:
- Actual scale (1:1): Drawing shows actual size
- Reduced scale (1:10): One unit on print represents ten units of actual object
- Enlarged scale (10:1): Ten units on print represents one unit of actual object

Revision block
Located in lower left-hand or upper right-hand corner. Lists all revisions made to the drawing after initial drafting.

Materials block (bill of materials)
Usually located just above title block. Lists all parts with part/stock numbers, quantities, sizes, and materials.

Chapter 4 - Graphs and charts

Overview
Graphs and charts are used to represent facts, statistics, or the relationship between physical properties. A visual or graphical description is often easier to understand than a numerical or verbal description.

Terminology
- Chart: A visual or graphical representation of data
- Graph: Same as chart

Types of graphs and charts
A graph or chart is a line or diagram that shows how one quantity depends on, changes, or relates to another.

Applications
Graphs and charts are used in three general ways:
• For graphical presentation of information
• For graphical analysis
• For computation or determination of values

Four common types:
1) Bar graph (bar chart or column chart)
2) Pie chart (sector chart)
3) X-Y graph (rectangular coordinate line graph)
4) Flow chart

Bar graph
Bar graphs visually represent numerical values through bars of different lengths or heights. Bars may be vertical or horizontal, begin at a baseline, and show the relationship between two or more related variables.

Particularly suitable for:
• Presenting information to non-technical audience
• Representing small numbers of plotted values
• Making simple comparison of two values along two axes
• Representing data for a total period

Unsuitable for:
• Comparing several series of data
• Plotting large numbers of values

Pie chart
Pie charts show individual parts as sectors in a circular area, communicating the relationship of these sectors to the total.

Commonly used to:
• Display data as percentages
• Present general overall view of information
• Show relationship between small number of values
• Emphasize amount of data rather than trend

X-Y graph
X-Y graphs show values of two related variables plotted as points on a coordinate grid. Points are successively connected to form continuous line or curve.

Used to:
• Compare large numbers of values in compact space
• Compare trends of several curves on one graph
• Calculate values that fall between plotted points

Reading X-Y graphs:
Values of two variables are plotted with reference to two axes perpendicular to one another, meeting at common origin or zero point.

Unsuitable for:
• Representing small numbers of plotted values
• Showing changes in absolute amounts
• Showing extreme or irregular data movements

Flow chart
Flow chart is schematic representation of a process, showing information in:
• Pictorial form
• Schematic symbols
• Labelled blocks
• Combination of all three

Locating data on graphs
To determine values from graphs:
1) Determine value on x-axis
2) Locate point on line coinciding with x-axis value (trace vertically)
3) Trace horizontal line to y-axis
4) Read corresponding value on y-axis

assignment_questions.explanation: Bar graphs begin at baseline and show variable relationships

Chapter 5 - Units of measurement and conversion factors

Overview
A gas technician/fitter needs to understand both the traditional and SI (metric) units of measurement, as both are common in technical manuals, specifications, drawings, and graphs.

Terminology
- Imperial units: A system of measurement derived from an earlier English system of measurement units
- International System of Units (SI): A rationalized, coherent, and simplified metric-based system of measurement

Units of measurement
The countries participating in the General Conference of Weights and Measures (CGPM), ISO, and IEC developed and approved the International System of Units (SI). Canada is a member of all these organizations.

Despite this, many measurements used in the gas industry continue to be in imperial units.

Prefixes indicating order of magnitude:
- G (giga): 1,000,000,000 = 10⁹
- M (mega): 1,000,000 = 10⁶
- k (kilo): 1000 = 10³
- d (deci): 0.1 = 10⁻¹
- c (centi): 0.01 = 10⁻²
- m (milli): 0.001 = 10⁻³
- µ (micro): 0.000001 = 10⁻⁶
- n (nano): 0.000000001 = 10⁻⁹
- p (pico): 0.000000000001 = 10⁻¹²

Note: In imperial measurements, "M" sometimes represents 1000 (not 1,000,000). Example: MBtu/h means one thousand Btu/h.

Imperial and SI units commonly used in gas industry:

Length: Inches (in), Feet (ft), Miles (mi) | Centimetres (cm), Metres (m), Kilometres (km)

Area: Square inches (in²), Square feet (ft²) | Square centimetres (cm²), Square metres (m²)

Volume of liquid: Gallon (gal) | Litre (L)

Volume of gas: Cubic feet (ft³) | Cubic metres (m³)

Flow rate of gas: Cubic feet per hour (ft³/h) | Cubic metres per hour (m³/h)

Calorific value: British thermal units per cubic foot (Btu/ft³) | Megajoules per cubic metre (MJ/m³)

Pressure: Pounds per square inch (psig), Inches water column (in w.c.) | Kilopascal (kPa)

Mass: Ounces (oz), Pounds (lb) | Grams (g), Kilograms (kg)

Temperature: Degrees Fahrenheit (°F) | Degrees Celsius (°C)

Heat (energy): British thermal units (Btu) | Joules (J)

Heat rate (power): Horsepower (HP), British thermal units per hour (Btu/h) | Watts (W), Kilowatts (kW)

Conversion factors
Used to calculate value of measurement as different unit. Common conversion factors:

- Btu/ft³ × 0.03723 = MJ/m³
- Btu/h × 0.00029295 = kW
- °F: (°F − 32) × 5/9 = °C
- ft × 0.3048 = m
- ft³ × 0.028317 = m³
- ft³/h × 0.028328 = m³/h
- gal × 4.546 = L
- US gal × 3.785 = L
- HP × 745.699 = W
- in × 25.4 = mm
- in² × 645.16 = mm²
- in w.c. × 249 = P
- in w.c. × 0.249 = kPa
- lb × 453.6 = g
- MJ/h × 0.2778 = kW
- oz × 28.35 = g
- psig × 6.894757 = kPa
